#Text=Erlangen
#Text=Erlangen is a city in Franconia , Germany .
#Text=It is home to most of the Friedrich-Alexander University ( two faculties are in Nuremberg ) and the Siemens company .
#Text=Understand
#Text=One third of the roughly 100 000 residents are involved with the university ( students , researchers , etc. ) , and another third work for Siemens .
#Text=Medicine is one of the specialties of the university , so you are in luck if you fall ill with more than six clinics in the city .
#Text=Tourist information

#Text=The Erlangen tourist info , Goethestraße 21a ( in the center of the city ; coming out of the central station turn left at the end of the square into Goethestraße , the office is in the second building to the right ) , ☏ +499131 8951-0 , ✉ tourist@etm-er.de .
#Text=M - Th 09:00 - 17:00 , F 09:00 - 15:00 , Sa 10:00-13:00. You can also get VGN tickets and advice on local public transit in the same office .
#Text=Early history , the Margraves and the Huguenots

#Text=While Erlangen can trace its history back to a first mention ( as " Villa Erlangon " ) over a thousand years ago , it was soon overshadowed by its neighbor , Nuremberg , which is 50-odd years younger .

#Text=The biggest lasting influence upon Erlangen was its former rulers , the Margraves from the Ansbach-Bayreuth branch line of the Hohenzollern ( the leaders of Prussia and later all of Germany ) dynasty .
#Text=They ruled the city for most of the early modern period , but preferred to reside in Bayreuth and Ansbach respectively most of the time .
#Text=When the French Protestants were expelled by Louis XIV , the Margrave , much like his distant relatives in Brandenburg , decided to invite them to come to Erlangen .

#Text=The old houses , the one-way streets of the " Huguenot-town " ( which are almost unnavigable unless you ride a bike like most locals do ) , and a centrally located rather impressive reformed church ( right next to Hugenottenplatz ) still bear witness to this era .
#Text=With the Huguenots a certain wealth entered town and Erlangen has been a center for various industries , trades and research ever since .
#Text=This was aided when the Margraves decided to open a new university in Erlangen , which later got two faculties in Nuremberg .

#Text=A common joke ( probably made up by a student of theology from Erlangen ) claims that Erlangen is the only German place mentioned in the Bible with the ( real sounding but fake ) quote " Suchet das Himmelreich zu erlangen " .
#Text=This can be translated either as " seek to reach heaven " or " Search for heaven in Erlangen " .
#Text=However , no such quote is to be found in any common German version of the Bible .
#Text=Industrialization and World War II
#Text=When Erlangen became part of Bavaria in the first years of the 19th century , all universities in Franconia were to be shut down in favor of the universities of " Old-Bavaria " .
#Text=But someone pointed out that Erlangen had a unique selling point no other university in the new kingdom had : an evangelical theological faculty .
#Text=As the new king wanted protestant ministers to be educated somewhere , he decided to shut down the university in Altdorf ( near Nuremberg ) , and retain the university of Erlangen .
#Text=This proved a good decision for the city and with the industrialization , Erlangen became an important center of cotton processing plants .
#Text=ErBa ( Erlangen-Bamberg ) and Baumwollspinnerei ( Cotton factory ) are names from this period and still found in some place names in Erlangen .
#Text=While Erlangen was not unaffected by the Nazis and the Second World War , it was much less bombed than Nuremberg or Munich and in the waning days of the war .

#Text=The mayor ( who had been member of the Nazi party since 1933 ) and a high ranking general called Walter Lorleberg somehow managed to surrender the town to the American army despite orders to the contrary .
#Text=While the details are not known , Lorleberg died in the waning hours of the war , presumably killed by fanatic Nazis or through suicide .
#Text=A square in Erlangen is still named after him , which is controversial because he was a high ranking Nazi general .
#Text=Post war
#Text=After the war Siemens decided to move out of Berlin , which had been almost entirely destroyed .
#Text=To avoid the Soviets , they decided to build two headquarters in the American Zone , one of which would become Erlangen ( the other is in Munich ) .
#Text=This decision continues to benefit the city .
#Text=Siemens ' policies and decisions are followed almost as intensely as mayoral politics in Erlangen .
#Text=Erlangen grew rapidly from just under 30,000 inhabitants in 1925 .
#Text=Between people moving in and the incorporation of suburbs such as Dechsendorf , by 1975 the city had reached 100,000 people .
#Text=Thus attaining " Großstadt " status , which it still holds at population figures below 110 000 but above 100 000 .

column1: #Text=Erlangen had been the site of a garrison of the Bavarian Army since the mid 19th century and became a garrison of the German Army after World War I .
#Text=After the defeat of the Nazis in 1945 , the garrison was taken over by the US Army and expanded .
#Text=However , in the course of post-cold war downsizing of the troop presence , the garrison was closed in the early 1990s and has been turned into direly needed housing as well as nature reserve .
#Text=It is sometimes cited as an example of the " peace dividend " that many hoped would result after the cold war as military installations were turned over to civilian uses .

column1: #Text=Erlangen 's mayor from 1972-1996 , Dietmar Hahlweg , decided against building more and bigger streets or relying solely on public transport .
#Text=Instead he encouraged cycling as a means of getting around investing in infrastructure and riding a bike to work himself to set an example .

#Text=Today many residents ( even those working for Siemens and the mayor ) get to work on their bikes every day , and the cars clogging the streets often have number-plates of the surrounding villages and suburbs .
#Text=Erlangen thrives economically today , but is still dependent upon its university and Siemens .
#Text=If either coughs , the city gets pneumonia .
#Text=By plane
#Text=The next airport is in Nuremberg ( NUE ) with domestic and limited international connections .

#Text=The U-Bahn ( subway ) takes you to the Nuremberg main station in roughly 12 minutes , from where you can take a wide variety of inter-city ( ICE and IC ) , regional ( RE and RB ) and commuter-trains ( the S-Bahn ) to Erlangen .
#Text=The subway and regional trains are fully integrated within the VGN tariff union .
#Text=There is also a direct bus ( line 30 ) from the airport to downtown Erlangen every 20 minutes on weekdays ( 40 minutes on weekends ) .
#Text=This option takes a bit under half an hour .
#Text=If you are flying in from Frankfurt airport ( FRA ) , there are connections with one change ( in Nuremberg ) from the train station integrated into the airport .
#Text=Erlangen can be reached somewhat more quickly from Munich Airport ( MUC ) , although it is one more stop away on the train .
#Text=For more on combined train and flight tickets see this article .
